prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 imaging of Abell 370
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum mapping over the deep HST/WFC3 FOV, which includes the high magnification (>10) region found via mass models (Richard+10). Baseband frequecies will obtain 1.1mm continuum and potentially catch rare redshifted [CII] at z~6-7.
Abell 370: z=0.375, R_einstein(z=2)~39", M_einstein(z=2)=2.8e14, high-mag area u(z=2)~3.0 arcmin^2, ~30 multiply-lensed images (pre-HFF)
Abell 370 was recently approved and scheduled with HST, which is why it was not initially requested in Cycle 2 and is request here.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the remaining FF clusters in order to assemble a submm sample which takes advantage of both the negative K-correction and gravitational lensing to probe deep into the submm population and provide constraints on undetected sources. Characterization of ALMA detections will benefit from the best available ancillary data. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).
Our sensitivity is motivated by the desire to securely constrain both the turnover and fall-off of the 1.1mm number counts ~1.5-2 dex below the loosely determined ~2 mJy turnover found by Scott+12, Karim+13, and Barger+14. Based on an extrapolation of the current number counts and best-fit semi-analytic simulations (e.g., Fig 2), we predict ~7 objects/arcmin^2 down to ~0.35mJy over the 2' x 2' FOV of HST/WFC3, once we correct for magnification and the smaller volume from lensing. To constrain the decline in the differential number counts, we want 6 x 0.3 dex bins (in intrinsic "de-lensed" flux) below 2 mJy containing at least ~5-10 objects each. This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100-150 objects in total, or a survey of at least 14-21 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 6 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of 0.067mJy to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.35 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density.
Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.

We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This allow us to optimize our continuum S/N (entire ~7.5GHz bandwidth) while still maintaining enough spectral resolution to be sensitive to strong serendipitous line emission (e.g., line widths of ~50 km/s, such as those detected from the z=4.7 [CII] detection by Carilli+13 or simulated by Vallini13). Based on the simulations of Geach+Papadopulus12, we only expect to detect CO line emission from a few (~3) objects down to the 0.35mJy continuum limit unlensed and ~10 once we apply the lensing boosts for all ALMA FFs. However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~20-30 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.

We adopt Nyquist sampling to generate a homogenous rms continuum map. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, 126 contiguous pointings are required to map the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. While ACA data could be employed to provide better sensitivity to extended emission in the gravitational arcs, we stress that the ACA is NOT required for our main science. Our desired resolution is listed as 1.0", so as to detect all but the largest structures (e.g., Hodge+13), enabling relatively robust number counts and to constrain any ``dark'' (i.e., ALMA only) sources/arcs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 imaging of Abell 1063S
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum mapping over the deep HST/WFC3 FOV, which includes the high magnification (>10) region found via mass models (Monna+14, Zitrin+15). Baseband frequecies will obtain 1.1mm continuum and potentially catch rare redshifted [CII] at z~6-7.
RXJ2248/Abell 1063S: z=0.348, R_einstein(z=2)~31", M_einstein(z=2)=1.4e14, high-mag area u(z=2)~2.4 arcmin^2, ~30-40 multiply-lensed images (pre-HFF)
Abell 1063S was recently approved and scheduled with HST, which is why it was not initially requested in Cycle 2 and is requested here.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the remaining FF clusters in order to assemble a submm sample which takes advantage of both the negative K-correction and gravitational lensing to probe deep into the submm population and provide constraints on undetected sources. Characterization of ALMA detections will benefit from the best available ancillary data. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).
Our sensitivity is motivated by the desire to securely constrain both the turnover and fall-off of the 1.1mm number counts ~1.5-2 dex below the loosely determined ~2 mJy turnover found by Scott+12, Karim+13, and Barger+14. Based on an extrapolation of the current number counts and best-fit semi-analytic simulations (e.g., Fig 2), we predict ~7 objects/arcmin^2 down to ~0.35mJy over the 2' x 2' FOV of HST/WFC3, once we correct for magnification and the smaller volume from lensing. To constrain the decline in the differential number counts, we want 6 x 0.3 dex bins (in intrinsic "de-lensed" flux) below 2 mJy containing at least ~5-10 objects each. This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100-150 objects in total, or a survey of at least 14-21 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 6 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of 0.067mJy to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.35 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density.
Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.

We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~20-30 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.

We adopt Nyquist sampling to generate a homogenous rms continuum map. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, 126 contiguous pointings are required to map the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. Our desired resolution is listed as 1.0", so as to detect all but the largest structures (e.g., Hodge+13), enabling relatively robust number counts and to constrain any ``dark'' (i.e., ALMA only) sources/arcs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 imaging of MACSJ0717.5+3745
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum mapping over the deep HST/WFC3 FOV, which includes the high magnification (>10) region found via mass models (Zitrin+09; Zitrin+15). Baseband frequecies will obtain 1.1mm continuum and potentially catch rare redshifted [CII] at z~6-7.
MACS J0717.5+3745: z=0.545, R_einstein(z=2)~55", M_einstein(z=2)=2.3e14, high-mag area u(z=8)~3.5 arcmin^2, ~50-60 multiply-lensed images (pre-HFF)
MACS0717 was dropped from Cycle 2 proposal due to feasibility concerns. Although close to the elevation limit that ALMA prefers to observe to (~30 deg), the observations remain feasible (observations will suffer from 30-40% shadowing, limited scheduling, and an elongated beam). but is sufficient for detection purposes.
ALMA will provide far superior coverage and sensitivity vs any other current facility in a reasonable amount of time.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the remaining FF clusters in order to assemble a submm sample which takes advantage of both the negative K-correction and gravitational lensing to probe deep into the submm population and provide constraints on undetected sources. Characterization of ALMA detections will benefit from the best available ancillary data. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).
Our sensitivity is motivated by the desire to securely constrain both the turnover and fall-off of the 1.1mm number counts ~1.5-2 dex below the loosely determined ~2 mJy turnover found by Scott+12, Karim+13, and Barger+14. Based on an extrapolation of the current number counts and best-fit semi-analytic simulations (e.g., Fig 2), we predict ~7 objects/arcmin^2 down to ~0.35mJy over the 2' x 2' FOV of HST/WFC3, once we correct for magnification and the smaller volume from lensing. To constrain the decline in the differential number counts, we want 6 x 0.3 dex bins (in intrinsic "de-lensed" flux) below 2 mJy containing at least ~5-10 objects each. This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100-150 objects in total, or a survey of at least 14-21 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 6 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of ~0.070mJy to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.35 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density.
Critically, for MACS0717, we must factor in an additional ~20% for shadowing (which the OT fails to account for. Thus, we must go a factor of 20% fainter, or a factor of 1.36 longer). Thus we set our sensitivity to 0.060mJy.
Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.

We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This allow us to optimize our continuum S/N (entire ~7.5GHz bandwidth) while still maintaining enough spectral resolution to be sensitive to strong serendipitous line emission (e.g., line widths of ~50 km/s, such as those detected from the z=4.7 [CII] detection by Carilli+13 or simulated by Vallini13). Based on the simulations of Geach+Papadopulus12, we only expect to detect CO line emission from a few (~3) objects down to the 0.35mJy continuum limit unlensed and ~10 once we apply the lensing boosts for all ALMA FFs. However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~20-30 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.

We adopt Nyquist sampling to generate a homogenous rms continuum map. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, 126 contiguous pointings are required to map the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. While ACA data could be employed to provide better sensitivity to extended emission in the gravitational arcs, we stress that the ACA is NOT required for our main science.
Our desired resolution for the other clusters is 1.0" to not resolve out emission, although our A2744 data show most emission is compact (<0.5"). However, we request 0.5" for MACS0717 (e.g., C36-4) since the beam will be more 2x elongated in one direction anyway and a more extended configuration will help limit shadowing losses (which we estimate from simulations should be ~20%). The resulting beam should enable relatively robust number counts, source locations, and >0.7-1.0" shapes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In cycle 2, ALMA observed the first 3 Frontier Fields clusters in band 6. We propose to complete this project by mapping the remaining 3 clusters in similar detail, providing a uniform sample of >100 ALMA detected objects and individual and stacked submm constraints on 10,000s of targets in the field. The observations stand to provide a long-lasting legacy and seed many future studies of faint submm galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00999.S, Lensing through Cosmic Time: ALMA Constraints on "Normal" Galaxies in the HST Fronter Fields, Bauer
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
